column1: Djibouti City (also called Djibouti; Arabic: مدينة جيبوتي‎
column2: French: Ville de Djibouti
column3: Somali: Magaalada Jabuuti
column4: Afar: Magaala Gabuuti) is the eponymous capital and largest city of Djibouti. It is located in the coastal Djibouti Region on the Gulf of Tadjoura.

column1: Djibouti City has a population of around 562
column2: 000 inhabitants
column3: which counts for over 70% of the country's population. The settlement was founded in 1888 by the French
column4: on land leased from the ruling Somali and Afar Sultans. During the ensuing period
column5: it served as the capital of French Somaliland and its successor the French Territory of the Afars and Issas.

column1: Known as the Pearl of the Gulf of Tadjoura due to its location
column2: Djibouti City is strategically positioned near the world's busiest shipping lanes and acts as a refueling and transshipment center. The Port of Djibouti is the principal maritime port for imports to and exports from neighboring Ethiopia. Djibouti-Ambouli International Airport is the main domestic airport
column3: connecting the capital to various major global destinations. Djibouti City has the second-largest economy of any city in the Horn of Africa after Addis Ababa.

column1: == History ==
There is evidence of human settlement on the eastern coastline of Djibouti dating back to the Bronze Age.
From 1862 until 1894

column5: including a peninsula composed of insubmersible plateaux

column7: a future bridgehead for their African and Asian interests. It is then that this point begins to be used as departure for caravans towards Harar.

column3: including trade in Harari coffee and khat. Djibouti City began to develop as a commercial center. In 1932

The captain decides to flood the holds and run aground his ship in the middle of the harbor of Djibouti. The inconvenience will be significant for the port traffic. But we then decided to use the wreck as a promontory of a new deep-water port

column2: Djibouti City was hit by Italian airstrikes on June 21

column8: prompting Nouailhetas to institute a brutal reign of terror against Europeans and Natives. Famine set in malnutrition-related diseases took many lives
column9: 70% of them women and children and many townsfolk left for the hinterland. The locals named the blockade the carmii
column10: a word for a type of sorghum usually reserved for cattle
column11: but used as human food at the height of the famine. The head doctor at the hospital committed suicide in despair. Only a few Arab dhows (boutres) managed to run the blockade to Djibouti and Obock and only two French ships from Madagascar managed to run it.

column13: completing its liberation. The official handover took place at 10:00 p.m. on 28 December. The first governor appointed under the Free French was André Bayardelle.

column12: the plan of Djibouti City consisted of four main features: a hierarchical system of streets laid out in a grid

column2: the population of Djibouti City was over 110
column4: the city has served as the administrative and commercial capital of the Republic of Djibouti.

column1: == Geography ==
=== Topography ===
Djibouti City is the capital and largest settlement in Djibouti
column2: situated in the Horn of Africa. The city is located in eastern Djibouti
column3: approximately 21 kilometres (13 miles) northwest of the Somalia border. It is a seaport
column4: with the only sheltered harbour on the western side of the Gulf of Tadjoura. The wadi of Ambouli
column5: flows through the city
column6: separating the older parts of the city from the Balbala district. The landscape around the city
column7: along with Djibouti's coastal lowlands
column8: is desert or semi-desert. The city's sandy beaches include Siesta Beach and Heron Beach. It is known as the "Pearl of the Gulf of Tadjoura" due to its location.

column1: === Vegetation ===
Djibouti City is rich in plant species partly because of its diversity of habitats
column2: including beaches
column3: mangroves and semi-arid lands. The most prevalent plant communities are the African foxtail grass
column4: Urochondra
column5: Panicum turgidum  and Acacia tortilis.

column1: === Geology ===
Djibouti City is subject to earthquakes because of its location on the Somali Plate and Red Sea Rift. The geological instability has produced numerous faults
column2: which cause earthquakes but most of them are too small to be felt.

column1: === Districts ===
Djibouti City's urban area is partitioned into 31 districts
column2: which include Heron
column3: Gabode
column4: Haramous and Makka Al Moukarama. Balbala suburb has been officially part of the city since 1987
column5: and is divided into 18 districts.

column1: === Climate ===
Djibouti City has an arid climate (Köppen: BWh). It is characterised by very hot rainless summers and a very warm
column2: slightly wetter winter season. Most of the annual precipitation falls between October and May. The city sees on average 163.5 millimetres (6.44 in) of rainfall per year. Average high temperatures range from 29 °C (84 °F) during the months of December
column3: January and February
column4: to about 42 °C (108 °F) in July. There are two seasons: a hot dry season from May to October and a cooler season with more precipitation from November to April (winter). The rainfall on the coast usually occurs between November to March
column5: whereas further inland it falls between April to October. In the summer months
column6: temperatures routinely exceed 40 °C (104 °F)
column7: with relative humidity at its lowest point of the year. Sunshine is abundant in the city
column8: averaging eight to ten hours a day year-round. It is lowest during the rainy period
column9: when there is some coastal fog and greater cloud coverage as warm air passes over the cool sea surface. However
column10: precipitation is highly variable and long periods without any rainfall occur throughout the year. Unusual episodes of heavy rain sometimes occur
column11: with a maximal 224 millimetres (8.82 in) falling in November 1949.This climate zone has summers that reach a maximum temperature of 41.7 °C (107.1 °F) and a minimum temperature of 32 °C (90 °F). Winters have average nighttime temperatures of 21 °C (70 °F) and a daytime maximum temperatures of 29 °C (84 °F). There are barely any days in the year without sunshine
column12: and even during the winter there are many clear days.

column1: == Demographics ==
Djibouti City is a multi-ethnic town. It has a population of around 529
column2: 000 residents (Djiboutians)
column3: making it by far the largest settlement in the country. The two largest ethnic groups are the Somali and the Afars
column4: both Cushitic speaking Cushitic peoples. The city's urban landscape is shaped by many communities. The ethnic make-up of Djibouti City changed in 1990s
column5: when significant numbers of Ethiopians and Somali immigrants arrived in the city
column6: with Djibouti City nicknamed the "French Hong Kong in the Red Sea" due to its cosmopolitan urbanism.The majority of local residents speak Somali (303
column7: 100 speakers) or Afar (101
column9: which are the mother tongues of the Somali and Afar ethnic groups
column10: respectively. Both languages belong to the larger Afroasiatic family. There are two official languages in Djibouti: Arabic (Afroasiatic) and French (Indo-European).

column1: Arabic is of social
column2: cultural and religious importance. In formal settings
column3: it consists of Modern Standard Arabic. Colloquially
column4: about 40
column5: 000 local residents speak the Ta'izzi-Adeni Arabic dialect
column6: also known as Djibouti Arabic. French was inherited from the colonial period and is the primary language of instruction. About 14
column7: 200 Djiboutians speak it as a first language. Immigrant languages include Omani Arabic (38
column9: 400 speakers).Djibouti's population is predominantly Muslim. Islam is observed by 94% of the nation's population (around 740
column11: whereas the remaining 6% of residents are Christian adherents. The Diocese of Djibouti serves the small local Catholic population

column1: === Religion ===
Among the places of worship
column2: they are predominantly Muslim mosques. There are also Christian churches and temples : Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church
column3: Roman Catholic Diocese of Djibouti (Catholic Church)
column4: Protestant churches
column5: Evangelical Churches.

column1: == Cityscape ==
=== Architecture ===

Djibouti City is home to different architectural styles that represent various periods in its history. The old section is filled with bazaars and souks nestled along narrow streets. Djibouti City has wide streets
column2: restaurants
column3: Plaza (town squares) and cafes while many of the boulevards are lined with trees. It is serves as both a center for commerce and entertainment
column4: as well as a residential area. To accommodate the growing middle class
column5: many new apartments and housing developments are being constructed in and around the city. A few of the building fronts have been renovated and date back to the 19th century. The Place of 27 June in the city center is also distinguished by its Moorish-inspired arches. Due to its numerous exotic edifices and structures
column6: the city has also been likened to a European settlement.

column1: == Administration ==
Djibouti City has the distinction of being both a city and an administrative province. The Djibouti Region is one of the six regions of Djibouti. It borders the Gulf of Tadjoura to the north and east
column2: and the Arta Region to the south and west. The Djibouti Region is the smallest province in the country
column3: but also the region with the highest population. Djibouti Region occupies an area of 200 square kilometres (77 square miles). It is the smallest region in Djibouti
column4: and contains the national capital
column5: Djibouti City.

column1: Djibouti City has been the capital of Djibouti since independence in 1977. Due to its maritime location
column2: it was the logical choice as the young republic's administrative center. Following independence
column3: Djibouti City continued with its status as the country's political and cultural hub. It is the seat of the government and home to all the national institutions: the government house
column4: the parliament
column5: ministries
column6: the presidential palace
column7: the vice-presidential residence
column9: judicial bodies and other public organizations.

column1: The Djibouti City includes three communes:
The commune of Ras-Dika whose territory corresponds to the 6th arrondissement.
The commune of Boulaos regroups the 1st
column2: 2nd and 3rd arrondissements.

column1: The town of Balbala includes the 4th and 5th arrondissements.
Djibouti City also serves as a hub for various state agencies
column2: as well as continental and international organizations. The Social Development Agency of Djibouti (Agence de Développement Sociale de Djibouti) has its head offices here
column3: as does the Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD) trade bloc. Additionally
column4: the Regional Somali Language Academy
column5: a language regulator established in June 2013 by the governments of Djibouti
column6: Somalia and Ethiopia
column7: has its headquarters in the city.Djibouti City is also home to the Armoured Regiment of Djibouti. The French 5th Overseas Interarms Regiment has served as the Djibouti garrison since 1 November 1969.

column1: === Law enforcement ===
The Djibouti National Police
column2: founded in 1977 in the locality of Djibouti City
column3: has law enforcement jurisdiction over the area.

column1: == Culture ==
National Archives & National Library of Djibouti is the main museum in the city. For much of its recent history
column2: the town was characterized by roadside markets and small shops that sold a wide variety of goods. The culture of Djibouti City has evolved under the influence of many different peoples and civilizations
column3: including Somali
column4: Afar
column5: Yemeni and French traditions. The capital is home to a large number of mosques in various architectural styles
column6: which date from different historical periods. Five times a day
column7: Muslims are called to prayer from the minarets of the city's many masjids. Additionally
column8: the local opera is a traditional form of musical theater well known throughout the nation. The Djiboutian attire is typical of several countries in the Horn of Africa.

column1: === Media ===

Djibouti City has long been a center of media in the country. The first forms of public film display in the city and Djibouti at large were newsreels of key events during the early colonial period. The Djibouti City-based Radio Television of Djibouti is the principal national public service broadcaster. RTD airs 24 hours a day
column2: and can be viewed both within Djibouti and abroad via terrestrial and satellite platforms. Several newspapers
column3: magazines and printing facilities have their offices in the capital. Additionally
column4: Djibouti City is a center for broadcast media
column5: with a number of radio and television stations airing from there. Various film and music productions are also filmed in the city.

column1: === Cuisine ===
Djibouti City has long been renowned for its diverse cuisine. Traditional Somali
column2: Afar and Yemeni delicacies are served alongside international dishes; especially French culinary staples. The Yemeni dish mandi is also a popular meal
column3: particularly during lunchtime. Several other popular dishes feature seafood and meat
column4: including Fah-fah (spicy boiled beef soup).

column1: Additionally
column2: there are a number of restaurants located throughout the city. These establishments serve everything from traditional dishes
column3: to gourmet delicacies
column4: to fast food and snacks. Among the more popular  eateries in the capital are the Café de la Gare and the Zip Zap Restaurant and Shisha Lounge. There are fast food restaurants
column5: such as Pointburger and Burger City.

column1: === Festivals ===
Annual events and celebrations in Djibouti City include Independence Day
column2: which is celebrated on 27 June. The Muslim festivals of Eid al-Fitr and Eid al-Adha also feature prominently in the city's cultural observances
column3: events and celebrations. Additional local
column4: national and international events are held here throughout the year.

column1: === Sports ===
Football is the most popular sport in Djibouti
column2: and Djibouti City has a number of sporting teams that compete in national and regional leagues. Basketball is also a second popular sport in the city. The city is home to El Hadj Hassan Gouled Aptidon Stadium
column3: which plays host to the Djibouti Cup and to football teams from the Djibouti Premier League. Djibouti City has established a high-profile reputation as a host city of international sporting events. At the beginning of the 20th century
column4: a number of sporting institutions were established in the city
column5: particularly in school and college settings.

column1: == Main sights ==
=== Shopping ===
Foreign visitors to Djibouti City usually like to frequent the shops on Bender Road (Rue de Bender)
column2: where myriad things ranging from traditional fabrics and leather products can be found at bargain prices. The newly built Casino Supermarket (Casino Supermarché) is the capital's largest such shopping center. For fresh produce
column3: meat
column4: clothing
column5: and other goods and services
column6: the open Ryad Market (Marché de Ryad) is a commercial outlet of choice.

column1: === Palaces ===
The presidential palace is the official residence and principal workplace of the President of Djibouti. It overlooks the Gulf of Tadjoura
column2: with access to both the harbour and airport.

column1: === Parks ===
Djibouti City has several public parks. The largest of these is the Lagarde Park.
=== Nature Reserve ===
The DECAN Refuge is about 10 km southeast of Djibouti City. Its a association takes in endangered animals
column2: often victims of poaching
column3: protection of the Cheetahs
column4: Lions
column5: Caracals
column6: Ostrichs
column7: (seriously endangered species) and other wild animals
column8: victims of poaching. There are plans to extend it from 30 acres to 600 acres
column10: which would encompass a mangrove area. DECAN also runs education programs for school kids.

column1: == Economy ==
As the capital of and largest city in Djibouti
column2: most local businesses have their headquarters in Djibouti City. Djibouti Telecom
column3: the largest telecommunications company in the country
column4: is based here. During its existence
column5: Djibouti Airlines also had its head office in the city. Djibouti City is the financial hub to many entrepreneurial industries ranging from construction
column6: retail
column7: import and export

column1: Cargo operations at the Port of Djibouti are the chief economic activity of Djibouti. The city's port is the terminus for Ethiopian oil transport and export. Increase in railway infrastructure has further enabled Ethiopian and Eritrean oil products to reach the capital.
=== Banking ===
The banking sector is one of the principal foundations of Djibouti's economy. The financial sector of the Republic of Djibouti has grown dramatically in recent years
column2: a process that began in the early 2000s
column3: and that was in large part prompted by an explosion the number of exchange agencies and remittances throughout the country. The Djiboutian financial sector
column4: with total assets of 265 billion DJF or 10.2 per cent of GDP
column5: has not been affected by the international financial crisis. Djibouti has been considered an oasis of peace and a model of political stability in a region.

column1: === Business ===

Djibouti City is introducing itself as a business hub. The city's skyline is being continuously transformed through the emergence of new projects. The business sector is largely concentrated in the service sector. Commercial activities revolve around the country's free trade policies and strategic location as a Red Sea transit point.
=== Tourism ===
Tourism in Djibouti is centered in the Djibouti region. City landmarks include historic buildings
column2: two important public squares
column3: and the Hall of the People. Many private companies offer organized tours of these sites. Known as the "Pearl of the Gulf of Tadjoura"
column4: the city's sandy beaches are also popular tourist attractions.

column1: Khor Ambado lies on the outskirts of Djibouti city
column2: around fifteen kilometres (9.3 miles) from the city center. A popular local attraction
column3: this beach has a number of restaurant establishments overlooking the sea. Doraleh is another beach situated about eight miles (13 kilometres) from the capital
column4: on a paved road that winds through the dunes of volcanic rocks. With its main restaurant
column5: Doraleh is a favorite hangout on Fridays leading up to the weekend. Other prominent beaches in the city include Siesta Beach and Heron Beach.

column1: The two small Maskali and Moucha islands are situated an hour's boat ride from Djibouti City. They feature madreporic mangroves
column2: with a rich seabed and colorful algae. Various fish species can also be found in the local coral gardens
column3: including groupers
column4: jacks and barracuda.Another notable city landmark is La Place du 27 Juin
column5: a street named after Djibouti's independence day. The Place Mahamoud-Harbi (formerly Place Rimbaud) was similarly named in honor of a prominent local figure
column6: erstwhile Vice President of the Government Council Mahmoud Harbi.

column1: === Hotels ===

Djibouti city has over 40 hotels. Most are situated within the capital area or along the Djibouti Palace Kempinski's beachfront. Among the more prominent hotel establishments and guest houses are the Apart Hotel Moulk Center
column2: the Hotel La Siesta
column3: the Sheraton Djibouti Hotel located on the waterfront
column4: the Kempinsky Hotel
column5: the Hotel Bellevue
column6: the Hotel Casino Impérial
column7: and the Hotel Acacias on Avenue F. d'Esperey.

column1: == Transport ==
=== Road ===
Djibouti City is a major transportation hub
column2: served by a comprehensive public transport network. Roads leading out of the city connect it to other national localities and to Somalia and Ethiopia. Public transportation is provided through buses stationed at the Djibouti City Bus Service Enterprise. The city at large serves as a point of intersection for the main roads and highways linking different parts of the country. It is one of the most accessible urban areas in the country
column3: where one can find public and private transportation 24 hours a day and 7 days a week. A significant number of the city's residents use the local informal minibuses and taxis
column4: which include a fleet of 400 green-and-white taxis. The main bus hub in Djibouti City is the Central Bus Station
column5: located at the crossing of Rue de Bender.

column1: Djibouti City is served primarily by the Djibouti-Ambouli International Airport. It is the second largest airport in the Horn of Africa
column2: and offers flights to numerous global destinations. As of 2016
column3: the largest services using the airport include Air Djibouti
column4: Yemenia
column5: Air France
column6: Flydubai
column7: Ethiopian Airlines
column9: Kenya Airways and Qatar Airways. It is the largest airport in Djibouti and serves as a major gateway for travellers to the Horn of Africa and the world. Located approximately 6 kilometres (3.7 miles) from the city centre
column10: the airport was opened in 1948. Originally a modest-sized facility
column11: the airport grew considerably in size in the post-independence period after numerous successive renovation projects. Outbound international travel from the Djibouti-Ambouli International Airport accounts for the majority of all air passengers traveling to and from Djibouti. Due to its strategic location
column12: the facility acts as a civil aviation hub for the rest of the country. This makes for a large number of departures and arrivals
column13: and it is not unusual for flights to be delayed in the holding pattern before landing.

column1: The Port of Djibouti is one of the largest and busiest seaports in the Horn region. As of 2013
column2: the container terminal at the port handles the bulk of the nation's trade. About 70% of the seaport's activity consists of imports to and exports from neighboring Ethiopia
column3: which depends on the harbour as its main maritime outlet. The port also serves as an international refueling center and transshipment hub. In 2012
column4: the Djiboutian government in collaboration with DP World started construction on the Doraleh Container Terminal
column5: a third major seaport intended to further develop the national transit capacity. A $396 million project
column6: it has the capacity to accommodate 1.5 million twenty foot container units annually.

column1: === Railway ===
Djibouti city is a terminus of the Addis Ababa–Djibouti Railway. For most of its length
column2: the railway runs parallel to the abandoned metre-gauge Ethio-Djibouti Railway. However
column3: the standard-gauge railway is built on a new
column4: straighter right-of-way that allows for much higher speeds. New stations have been built outside city centres
column5: and the old stations have been decommissioned. On 10 January 2017
column6: the 100 km section of Djibouti side was inaugurated in a ceremony held in the new station by Djibouti's President Ismail Omar Guelleh and Ethiopia's prime minister Hailemariam Dessalegn. There are two local railway stations: a passenger station at Nagad
column7: and a freight station at the Port of Doraleh.

column1: == Education ==
Djibouti City is the largest and most important educational center in the nation. It is home to many elementary and high schools
column2: religious schools
column3: and other institutions of learning. Public primary and secondary schools in the capital are run by the Ministry of Education. The Djiboutian public education is mainly French-speaking
column4: with a parallel Arabic-speaking sector. It culminated in the French baccalaureate issued by the Bordeaux Academy until 2014. Since 2015
column5: it has been a Djiboutian national diploma.

column1: Tertiary institutions in Djibouti City include:
University of Djibouti – largest and oldest university in Djibouti. Established in 1977
column2: it has approximately 15
column3: 000 students.

column1: Institut Supérieur des Sciences et de la Santé
